The multiple values of grassland ecosystems to humanity have long been recognised, ranging from direct benefits of agricultural production to indirect ES such as the regulation of climate and water quality, the provision of plants for medicinal purposes and pollination services
11 , among others. As such, grasslands are arguably one of the most valuable biomes for ecosystem service provision, but they are also among the most threatened by anthropogenic activities
56 . Many of the world’s grasslands are being lost due to land use change or degraded by poor grazing management or invasive species, thereby undermining their capacity to support biodiversity and provide ES
18 .
